reviewText:
Shutter lets you pilot a small drone into a supposedly haunted cabin as you try to shed light on what's causing the disturbances your client has reported.
It's a small, low budget game that can provide a good horror quick fix for those that don't mind its shortcomings.

PROS:

-the drone idea is quite original and works well

-a pretty good story rounded up by the report that'd be read after completing the game

-manages to create a creepy, unsettling ambiance

CONS:

-overall unremarkable graphics: before you get the HD camera upgrade first person view is so badly pixelated that I thought it was a bug

-easy, linear and short

-controlling a drone makes the things you'll face less threatening since you're not in harm's way: this changes in the last chapter when you're actually controlling a person though

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=478262347

Shutter was an enjoyable experience overall, its story was interesting enough to keep the game going for its 1 hour length and the places I explored and things I've met were appropriately creepy. While not scary per se the overall atmosphere was tense enough to make my hair stand on its end a few times.

Considering its low price it's a decent purchase for anyone looking for a quick, straightforward horror game.

reviewText:
It is always nice to see when the appropriate games get greenlit by the community - Shutter is another great example for that. This is a neat little game where we control a small RC car equipped with a camera - this surveillance unit is to be used to discover the strange occurrences surrounding a house.

We are constantly in contact with a software engineer, a guy who asks us where to go and what to take a photo of. The photos we then upload and await his further instructions. Occasionally he upgrades our software which basically means a camera with different modes for shooting (night vision, spectral vision). We take photos of objects, apparitions while experiencing some good-old survival horror scary stuff: suddenly closing doors, flickering lights, sudden blackouts and ghostly sounds / voices.

Regularly, we find notes telling us the story of the place and while it is not much it still contributes to the great atmosphere the game has. Graphics-wise the game is a bit rough around the edges - in-game menus are particularly ugly, still, Shutter has a good entertainment value for a couple of hours especially in case you are interested in something different than the AAA games out there.

I look forward to playing its sequel - I have to admit I have my expectations, though.

reviewText:
Basic concept of the game is that you are exploring an abandoned cabin with a RC robot car thing. As the game description says, as you progress you upgrade your robot dude giving you a better camera to keep getting pictures of paranormal things like floating objects, shadows, and orbs. The more pictures of paranormal activities/shadows, the more you progress.

Controls are a little janky, but felt fairly appropriate considering you arent controlling a person. You can use your battery power to get into a first person view, but when the battery runs out, you need to let it recharge. Letting you switch between the RC camera and a 3rd person view was a very nice touch.

In my opinion, they absolutely nailed the atmosphere. I might spook pretty easily, but I know I sat there jumping, flinching, and squeaking like a little girl the entire time I played (and especially at the end).

Graphics are a little dated (as a nod to PS1 era I guess), but the audio is very well done. Would have loved for an audio setting though. Im also very happy the dev didnt 100% rely on cheap jump scares. Also absolutely loved the story. Make sure you actually read the papers you find, as well as the police report in the menu (after you finish the game of course).

Outside of the bug mentioned in the description, I didnt find any major bugs. My mouse didnt lock in the window on windowed mode, but Im not sure if it was intended to be locked in or not. It wasnt game breaking for me though.

The only downside to the game is the length. The game is pretty short. Theres actually an achievement to finish in under 10 minutes I believe. So, expect to spend 30 minutes up to an hour on your first (blind) playthrough. I do wish the dev's had added some more meat to the story and expanded the house. It would have been cool to have more rooms to explore for more story pages.

All of that said, I very highly recommend the game. The story was creepy and the RC robot thing was a pretty cool/interesting concept. I definitely look forward to their next release.

reviewText:
I have to admit when I started playing this game I had very low expectations of it. But suprisingly I really enjoyed it.

I would describe this game as a puzzle horror game. You control a robot that is equipped with a camera. The robot has access to a computer that you use to receive orders from the person that sent you in there. The orders generally relate to power problems in the house that you are exploring and you are told to investigate these. However as you progress through the game you realize that there is a ghostly presence in the house haunting it.

This is when what I like to call the puzzle mechanic comes into play. The ghost will leave small clues around a room such as a floating plate. You need to take pictures of these items to trigger the puzzle. After taking the picture a new clue(?)" will be revealed which you need to discover by taking pictures. It is kinda detective style investigations. This is what I really enjoyed throughout the game. Sometimes it can take a while to find these clues but that just adds to the investigative fun.

The game does also feature a story. This is told by notes found around the area. It tells the story of the women who used to live in the house. In my opinion this is the weakest aspect of the game. The story is very cliched and is frankly not told very well. I noticed a fair amount of grammar mistakes in the story as well. Although I believe you can just leave the story and the rest of the game will be enjoyable. The story of your robot and investigation is also told via the person giving orders on the computer. This is also not very well told in my opinion but can't be skipped because the gameplay revolves around it.

Shutter features a very unique control system. It is meant to represent old school horror games. You see the robot through fixed camera angles. This means the robot is very hard to control initially. You use classic WASD and mouse to control it but due to the fixed camera angles it can get very confusing with what direction you are travelling in. This takes a long time to get used to but I believe that after you get used to it the unique control is what is another main strength of the game. If you don't like this control scheme you also have the option to view in first person mode. However this is on a timer and needs to be recharged frequently so can't be used constantly.

Now the horror aspect of the game is done fairly well. There were many points in the game where it made be jump through typical game jump scares. They were very well done and the majority of the time I wasn't expecting it. The voice acting on the ghost and atmospheric music is also very effective.

Theres also a few other smaller points that I feel I should mention-
The graphics aren't very impressive but I feel the particle effects are very well done.
I had a bug where at one point in the game all images where showing as a broken texture. Although this is aparently going to be fixed upon full release of the game.
There is no in game options menu but only an out of game one present. And it has no audio settings at all.
The game only took me just over an hour to complete so it is fairly short.
Overall I really enjoyed playing this game and I would definitely recommend it to people that enjoy horror and puzzle games.

reviewText: If you're looking for an intense horror experience, this game may, or may not be able to provide that. However, it still has a very tense atmosphere about it, and there are a few moments where you are truly scared. This game took a huge risk by making the player control a robot instead of another human being. By doing this, it takes away the fear that something can hurt you, since you're just a robot. This is perfectly shown in this game towards the end, when you play as a human for a little bit, and it becomes terrifying just entering the house. The game design is very innovative, and I enjoyed being able to control the robot from both a 1st and a 3rd person perspective. This game took a risk by making the player a non traditional character, and creating a non-traditional horror game, and I really wish that other horror games would also be willing to take risks instead of sticking to the same repetitive horror style. I loved the game, and would recommend it to anyone who dabbles in horror. reviewText: While this was a short game, the length fit the setting and story. I took about an hour to finish it on my second attempt (the first was aborted upon the discovery of how difficult it was to move around, I looked in vain for a way to change the control system) while taking the time to explore. It has a tense, creepy atmosphere to it despite the fact that you're piloting a small drone and thus shouldn't feel any sense of danger. I'm not fond of ghost stories in general, as so many of them rely on jump scares so it was quite a relief to find that this one didn't. The music is perfectly done, and really adds to the overall feeling of the game.\n\nThe actual gameplay consists of piloting your little drone around and taking pictures, which require a bit of timing to get right. Controls are imprecise, which was slightly frustrating but made it a slightly more immersive experience, I felt as if I was actually controlling the drone at some moments. My biggest annoyance was that I had to wait for the battery to recharge quite a bit, especially during the last chapter. Either a revamp of the battery system or an option to play entirely in first person would have been nice, but not needed. That's my one issue with this game though, which is more than I can say for most. Give this one a try for sure if you enjoy horror done right.

reviewText:
Tacky jump scares galore, copious cheesy ghost laughter, and abysmally animated apparitions.

Shutter is a fixed camera (except when it's not) horror game that clocks in at roughly one hour of gameplay. There are no side quests, no extra content, and no collectibles. It is one hour of slow, linear gameplay. One of my favorite games, Thirty Flights of Loving, finishes around 13 minutes. The difference is, a games like Thirty Flights of Loving offers a unique and engaging experience, whereas Shutter only offers boredom, confusion, and the occasional mocking laughter when something goes awry.

Shutter’s story is played out both in real time and through several ~100 year old diary entries you discover around the property of a client's old house you’ve been assigned to investigate for vandalism. You control a small robot using fixed security cameras installed around the house, as well as a camera mounted on the robot itself, in order to investigate reports of graffiti. You’re a part of a team that does this professionally, and you have a dispatcher named Barry who checks in with you via R.A.V.E.N. Shield (Remote Access View of Environment and Navigation). Barry guides you through the game and provides software (and somehow hardware) upgrades to your robot. The house ends up being haunted by ghosts of the past, including the author of the diary pages. In a strange way, this aspect reminds me a bit of Luigi's Mansion. But the story creates more questions than answers...

reviewText:
You get what you pay for, I guess.  Shutter  runs you about $3 for a horror experience pitched at the level of a low-tier episode of  Are You Afraid Of The Dark.  It's a haunted house story; the main gimmick is that instead of exploring the house in first-person with a flashlight, you instead pilot some kind of remote-controlled rover through it, with which you occasionally take pictures of suspicious-looking phenomena (hence the title of the game). The whole thing takes about 90 minutes to complete. There's diary entries to be found, and ghosts roaming the halls, etc. You know the drill.

There's nothing offensively bad about  Shutter.  There's also nothing particularly remarkable about it. I'll give the developers credit for an original approach to a shopworn genre, and for eschewing the use of cheap jump scares. I didn't find it scary, mainly because piloting a remote-controlled robot removes any sense of personal threat from the experience. I also don't remember any blood, so squeamish types should be all right with it.

I could just as easily have given this game a thumbs-up, because it's competently made and well-priced. I'm only voting it down because I just can't picture myself actively recommending it to anyone; it's too, well, not-scary for that. I wish the developers the best though, and the screenshots of the sequel (which apparently takes place in an abandoned prison, and are included as an extra" with the game) look interesting."

reviewText:
I was really excited to try this game. That excitement turned to frustration very quickly once I started playing. I found the battery system so unrealistic it was outrageous. You should be able to look around for longer than 2 seconds at a time, especially since that's the only way to actually find what you need to take a picture of. And having to run back to the generator in the dark when it's extremely hard to see with the lights on just to turn the generator back on is stupid, pointless, and maddening. If the guy talking to you from the security company can open doors he should be able to turn the generator on for you!

I kept having trouble with controlling the drone. At times it would only move sideways when I pushed forward or it would refuse to go through opened doors. Sometimes backing up and trying again worked but sometimes I had to restart the level to gain control. This was especially maddening when I was close to the end of a level since you always start back at the beginning.

I did not find this game scary at all. If I wasn't so frustrated or if I had actually been able to see the ghosts & shadows it may have been at least a little creepy. Flashes that last less than a second aren't scary! If those were ghosts then let us see them so we know they are ghosts. You can let then disappear or fade away after we get a good look. As-is they flash so quickly we don't know for sure what they are and just as quickly forget them. The shadows would be pretty spooky if we could see them better, but a shadow in a very poorly lit place is easily overlooked or dismissed as regular shadows.

The fish-eye lens was a dumb idea and almost made me quit playing before it was removed. It's hard enough to see in this game without giving us a headache too. Very bad idea!

The concept of this game is awesome, and if the things above were fixed I would highly recommend it. Those problems make the game no fun to play, and if I don't enjoy the game at least a little then I can't recommend it to others. I really hope the developers give this game an overhaul or make a better game using this concept.
